poem:
An Echo of Wages

In the clatter
       of morning trains,
worn hands grip
    promises unkept.

Beneath headlines,
    a nation sighs—
        trains roll forward,
        voices, silent.

The press howls,
    but the pulse remains;
labor's heartbeat —
    relentless rhythm.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Rightwing outrage at Labour’s pay deals is out of step with public mood Labour caves in to unions. Fears of a wage-price spiral. Back to the 1970s and a new winter of discontent. The Conservative party and its friends in the media have been in full cry since the government made an offer to train drivers last week aimed at ending two years of disruption on the railways. The rightwing press needed little prompting to". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
